misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for computing average acceleration from three double inputs (v0, v1, t) instead of reading 5 integers and summing only the even numbers as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads v0, v1, and t as doubles and computes the average acceleration ( (v1 - v0) / t ).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, identify which of those are even using n % 2 == 0, compute the sum of only the even numbers, and print that sum.
symptoms: Prompt asks for 'Enter v0, v1, and t:' instead of 5 integers.
Only three values are read from input, not five.
No loop is used to process multiple inputs.
No conditional check for even numbers appears in the code.
The output describes 'average acceleration' instead of 'Sum of even numbers'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between this exercise and a different physics-related programming problem (average acceleration), leading to implementing the wrong algorithm and I/O behavior.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read the problem statement and list the exact inputs, processing steps, and required output before coding. Then, design your program to match those steps: 5 integer inputs, loop over them, check n % 2 == 0, accumulate a sum, and print the final sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: All variable names, prompt text, and the printed message are consistent with an average acceleration problem and do not reference 5 integers or even numbers, indicating a clear mismatch with the given task.

evidence.note: The code reads three doubles, computes average acceleration, and prints it, instead of reading 5 integers and summing the even ones.

misconceptions.name: Fundamental Misinterpretation of Assignment Goal
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code that calculates average acceleration (A = (V1 - V0) / T), solving a problem entirely different from the requested 'Sum of Even Numbers'. All core functional requirements of the actual assignment (reading 5 integers, using a loop, checking for even numbers, accumulating sum) are entirely missing.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have confused the assignment prompt with a calculation based on a known physics formula, possibly from a previous or different task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required the student to read 5 separate integers, use a loop to process them, apply conditional logic (modulo operation) to filter for even numbers, and maintain an accumulator variable to calculate the required sum.
symptoms: The code reads 3 doubles (V0, V1, T) instead of 5 integers.
The calculated result is 'average acceleration' not the sum of even numbers.
Required loop structure is missing.
Conditional check for even numbers is missing.
Input prompt ('Enter v0, v1, and t:') contradicts the task requirement.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading the assignment question or submitting code intended for a different problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully review the assignment prompt. Focus on implementing iteration (a loop) to handle five inputs sequentially, then use conditional statements (if/modulo) inside the loop to identify and sum the even values.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student code is an unambiguous implementation of an unrelated physics problem, demonstrating a complete failure to address the core requirements of the 'Sum of Even Numbers' task.

evidence.note: Reads 3 double inputs (V0, V1, T) instead of 5 required integers, demonstrating a failure to meet input quantity, type, and variable context requirements.

evidence.snippet:
double A = (V1 - V0) / T;

System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + A);
evidence.note: Calculates and prints average acceleration, showing zero attempt at calculating the sum of even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Solving wrong problem
misconceptions.description: The student has solved a completely different problem. Instead of reading 5 integers and summing even numbers, the student wrote code to calculate average acceleration from three velocity and time inputs.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they should solve a physics problem involving acceleration calculation rather than the stated problem of summing even numbers from 5 integers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading exactly 5 integers from the user, identifying which ones are even, and printing their sum. The sample run clearly demonstrates: input 'Enter 5 integers: 3 8 2 7 4' should produce 'Sum of even numbers: 14'.
symptoms: Code reads only 3 inputs instead of 5
Code reads decimal values (nextDouble) instead of integers (nextInt)
Code calculates acceleration (V1-V0)/T instead of summing even numbers
Output message refers to 'average acceleration' not 'sum of even numbers'
No loop structure to process multiple inputs
No conditional logic to check if numbers are even
misconceptions.root_cause: Fundamental misunderstanding or misreading of the problem statement. The student may have consulted the wrong assignment or confused this with a different physics-related problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. The task is to: (1) read 5 integers, (2) check each one to see if it's even using n%2==0, (3) accumulate the sum of only the even numbers, (4) print the result. Use a loop to process all 5 inputs.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence because the submitted code solves a completely different problem (physics acceleration calculation) with different input/output requirements, different data types, and no attempt to address any of the stated rubric requirements.

evidence.note: The entire solution addresses acceleration calculation with 3 inputs, not the required problem of summing 5 even integers

misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to compute average acceleration from v0, v1, and t instead of reading 5 integers and summing the even ones. This indicates they are solving a different problem than the one assigned.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads v0, v1, and t as doubles and computes the average acceleration (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, check which of them are even using a condition like n % 2 == 0, and compute and print the sum of only those even numbers.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers.
Only three values are read from input, not five.
The values are treated as velocities and time, not as general integers.
The core computation is average acceleration (A = (V1 - V0) / T) instead of summing even numbers.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have mixed up this question with a different assignment (average acceleration) or is reusing code from another problem without adapting it to the current requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and restate it in your own words before coding. Ensure your input variables, the number of values read, and the final calculation directly match the specification: 5 integers in, sum of even numbers out.
related_concepts: Mapping requirements to code structure (inputs, processing, outputs)
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: All variable names, prompt text, and formula clearly correspond to an average acceleration problem, with no attempt to read 5 integers or to sum even numbers.

evidence.note: The code reads three doubles labeled v0, v1, and t and computes average acceleration, which does not match the requirement to read 5 integers and sum even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Complete Misunderstanding of Problem Requirements/Goal
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for a completely different physics problem (calculating average acceleration from initial velocity, final velocity, and time) instead of solving the assigned task (summing the even numbers from 5 user inputs). This demonstrates a foundational failure to adhere to assignment specifications.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the assignment was related to calculating average acceleration.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required reading 5 integers and calculating the sum of only the even numbers among them.
symptoms: Code calculates average acceleration 'A = (V1 - V0) / T'
Input prompts ask for 'v0, v1, and t'
Only 3 inputs are read instead of 5
Inputs are read as 'double' instead of 'integer'
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading the assignment prompt or substituting a similar, unrelated assignment solution.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read the assignment prompt: 'Write a program that reads 5 integers from the user and prints the sum of only the even numbers.' Focus on the control structures (loops, conditionals) and input types required for *this* specific task.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student's entire code structure and logic address a completely different computational problem, indicating a fundamental misinterpretation of the task.

evidence.note: The entire implementation solves for average acceleration, not the sum of even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Failure to Use Iteration for Repeated Input
misconceptions.description: The student did not implement any loop structure (for or while) necessary to handle a set number of inputs (5). This procedural failure prevents the efficient processing of multiple data points.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that reading sequential dedicated variables is sufficient, or that loops are not necessary if the number of inputs is small, even though the problem implies iteration/repetition.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To process multiple inputs efficiently (like 5 numbers), a `for` or `while` loop should be used to repeatedly read and process data.
symptoms: Multiple distinct variables are used for input handling (V0, V1, T)
No use of `for` or `while` keywords
misconceptions.root_cause: Lack of understanding regarding the necessity of loops when processing an iterative series of inputs.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review how to use a `for` loop to repeat a set of actions (reading input, checking condition, accumulating sum) a fixed number of times (in this case, 5).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student reads three inputs sequentially without any loop structure whatsoever.

evidence.note: Inputs are read individually via sequential statements, not within a loop structure required to process 5 inputs.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Data Type for Input Reading
misconceptions.description: The assignment explicitly requires reading integers. The student used `INPUT.nextDouble()` which reads floating-point numbers (`double`). While this is connected to the primary misconception of solving the wrong problem, it is also a data type error for the required task.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that `double` is the appropriate type for reading numerical input, or that the current problem requires floating point numbers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment specifies reading integers, which requires using `INPUT.nextInt()` and storing the values in `int` variables.
symptoms: Use of `INPUT.nextDouble()`
Declaration of input variables as `double`
misconceptions.root_cause: Mistake in associating the required input type (integer) with the correct Scanner method (`nextInt`).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ensure that if the problem calls for whole numbers (integers), you use the appropriate data type (`int`) and the corresponding Scanner method (`nextInt()`).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Code explicitly uses `double` variables and `nextDouble()` calls.

evidence.note: The Student reads doubles instead of the required integers.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student solved a completely different problem (calculating acceleration) instead of the assigned problem (sum of even numbers). This indicates a fundamental misunderstanding of what the assignment requires.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe this assignment is about calculating average acceleration from three velocity and time inputs (physics formula).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading exactly 5 integers, checking which ones are even using the modulo operator (%), summing only the even numbers, and printing the result.
symptoms: Code reads 3 inputs instead of 5
Code reads doubles instead of integers
Code calculates acceleration instead of sum of evens
No even/odd checking logic present
No loop structure to process multiple values
Output is acceleration, not a sum
misconceptions.root_cause: Student either copied code from a different (physics/acceleration) problem, did not read the assignment carefully, or completely misunderstood the problem statement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully: 'Read 5 integers and print the sum of only the even numbers.' Create a plan: (1) Use a loop to read 5 integers, (2) Check if each is even using n % 2 == 0, (3) Add even numbers to a running sum, (4) Print the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence—the submitted code solves a completely different problem (acceleration calculation) with different inputs, output format, and logic. There is no overlap with the assigned task.

evidence.note: The entire solution is for a physics acceleration problem, not for summing even numbers. Asks for v0, v1, t instead of 5 integers; calculates acceleration instead of sum of evens.
